ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I got more comfortable with the grammar of German and listening. I need more work on speaking, but the class is dedicated to strengthening that.

This course was so helpful in improving grammar and ability to understand and make more complex sentences. We learned so much over the semester. Also I liked how we had topics about German history and culture.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I think that a strength was how every unit covered a history/culture, vocab theme, and grammar section. So we were always working on all these skills. I also liked the structure of having a chapter test every two weeks instead of a larger test less often. One weakness is perhaps there was too much homework - German hw took up a LOT of time. Though in the long run it definitely had a positive impact on our German skills, it was hard to balance the homework along with everything else.
More vocabulary games, and perhaps a little more lenience with english in class if it means making sure we understand what is being said a little bit.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes. Professor Gehlker was an amazing Professor.
Yes, German is a fascinating language that really opens up your relationship with language once you internalize the very different grammar structure.
